_prev_prog_3.Description: This program relates to the receipt/unloading of 37% formaldehyde from bulk road tankers, storage in two 25Kl storage vessels and transfer to the process weigh vessel and resin reactor as a raw material in the production of melamine and urea formaldehyde thermoset resins.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ATC Biscoe, Inc.

Formaldehyde Handling - Process Safety/ Hazard Analysis
   
Analysis conducted by ATC Biscoe, Inc. on: 06/13/2006

Members Present: 
Varma Penmetsa         Production Manager
Carolyn Underwood    Environmental Director
Tom Ruedy             Operations Manager

Original Analysis conducted by GVK America, Inc. on: 10/07/2004

Members Present: 
S.A. Naqui               Director and Technical Advisor
Werner Weninger         Sr.Technologist, Consultant
Raju Kale             Operations Manager 
Partha Nanduri        Manager Engineering
Varma Penmetsa         Production Manager
Suresh Sobarad               Assistant Manager Electrical & Electronics        
  Wallace Fields         Operator
Jeff Davis            Operator
Sandra Beaver         Lab Analyst (Present for the part of session). 
                    

The initial process hazards analysis for Formaldehyde handling was done before commissioning of the plant by an experienced team with expertise in Engineering and process operations (Werner Weninger the Technologist, Zimmer, the Project Engineer for the Resin plant and Raju Kale, the then Engineering and Production Manager). A review of the PHA, with all the concerned personnel and an external consultant was done in order to update and revalidate the process for the adequacy of the operating procedure and emergency preparedness. 
The flow chart depicting the Formaldehyde handling is attached with this review. The MSDS with all the required data is also attached for reference. Wallace and Jeff described the unloading, storage and transfer of Formaldehyde to the group. 
The following points were discussed: 

Unloading 
1)  Personal protective equipment, such as full face respirator with Formaldehyde compatible breathing cartridges, Rubber/PVC gloves - in addition to shoes, shall be worn while handling Formaldehyde. 
2)  The unloading pump has a pressure switch in the discharge. The pump operation logic is controlled by the PLC. After 11 seconds of starting the pump, if the pressure in the discharge pipeline is below 15psi, the PLC trips the pump. T

his is to take care of any leakage at the pump, suction line or hose, which automatically cause the discharge pressure of the centrifugal pump to drop. 
    
3)  The storage tanks are provided with Ultrasonic level switches with digital indication.  Only one discharge valve corresponding with pumping into either Tank1 or Tank2 is opened. These valves are provided with limit switches, which go    as inputs into the PLC. If Tank1 valve is opened, the PLC logic monitors the level switch of Tank1. When the level reaches 90%, the Ultrasonic level switch gets made and the PLC automatically shuts off the pump and suction valve. 
4)  Before connecting the hose, the operator inspects the couplings on the both ends for the integrity of the 0 rings. 
5)  Unloading is done strictly adhering to the Operating instructions, a copy of which is attached with this review. 
6)  All the piping is made of Schedule 80 rated PVC and conforms to generally acceptable good engineering practices. 
7)  The suction line to the unloading pump needed an additional support to prevent any accidental breaking of the pipe while connecting and disconnecting the hose. The same was provided. In the future it is planned to replace the suction line with a stainless steel pipe to improve the strength of the pipe. 
8)  The automatic suction valve is fail safe type, which gets closed in case of power failure or loss of air pressure. 
9)  Formaldehyde tankers shall only be unloaded in the daytime, never in the darkness.                            
10)  In case of any abnormal situations, such as Leakage/Fire/Power failure, the operator gets the tanker outlet valve closed. Depending on the situation, the hose shall be disconnected as per the operating instructions. 
11) The personnel involved in the handling of Formaldehyde shall wash their hands with             soap upon completion of the operation. 

The above features were felt to be adequate for covering the foreseeable hazards in unloading the Formaldehyde

tanker. 

Transfer of Formaldehyde into Process 
1) Only one of the Tanks (Tank1 or Tank2) shall be put to use for process by opening the corresponding outlet valve to the suction of the Transfer pump. The Tank outlet valves are provided with Limit switches, which confirm opening and closing of the valves to PLC. The PLC requires one of the valves to be open for starting the pump. 
2) The Tanks and their outlet lines are made of FRP and appear to be in good shape. 
All the piping was made of Schedule 80 rating PVC and conforms to generally acceptable good engineering practices. 
3) The IFA weighing system calls for a programmed load(normally 3000 kgs) of Formaldehyde into the measuring tank. The measuring tank weight is constantly monitored by loadcells. The maximum charge into the measuring tank is predetermined by the loadcells capacity and is programmed into the IFA weighing system. The values of these limits shall not be changed/increased. The measuring tank has been provided with a high level float switch. In case of any accidental overcharge beyond the normal limit, the float switch shuts off the operation of the measuring tank (i.e. shuts off the inlet valve to the measuring tank and the corresponding pump) indicating as a fault on the panel. This fault will not reset until the level is brought below the safe limit. During normal operation, the IFA system sends the signal to the PLC, which starts the pump and opens the measuring tank inlet valve. Once the programmed weight in the measuring tank is reached the IFA system automatically shuts off the pump and the valve. 
4) The process had Formaldehyde as the first charged component into the measuring tank and then into the Reactor. Any leaks in the flange joints or passing of outlet valves of the measuring tank / Reactor could lead to a hazardous situation. Hence it was decided to change the sequence of the components and take water as the first component. In case of any leakage, the further operations can be s

topped and all consequential hazards can be prevented. 
5) The outlet line of Reactor is branched into 4 outlets and a drain line, each branch having an automatic valve. The drain line is put into the ditch through a hose. In case of passing of the drain valve, the fluid flow is not visible. Hence it was discussed and decided to modify the drain line arrangement. A Tundish(Funnel like equipment with high side walls) shall be provided with the outlet drain line stopping just above the Tundish. The drain line of Tundish shall be put into the ditch. This would enable the operator to notice any passing of the drain valve. 
6) The operator shall make sure that the Water ring vacuum pump is started before the components charging is started. The Vacuum from the pump keeps all the vapors from Formaldehyde inside the reactor.  
7) In case of any problems with the vacuum pump, the operator shall keep the reactor lid closed to prevent release of vapors into the atmosphere. 
8) The measuring tank inlet valve (automatic) is fail safe type, which gets closed in case of power failure or loss of air pressure. 
9)In case of any abnormal situations, such as Leakage/Fire/Power failure, the operator shall close the lid of the reactor. 
10)The personnel involved in the handling of Formaldehyde shall wash their hands with soap upon completion of the operation. 

The above features were felt to be adequate for covering the foreseeable hazards in transferring the Formaldehyde into the Reactor. 

Maintenance 
Maintenance of the pumps, piping, interlocks, PLC, and instrumentation shall be done with good engineering practices. Replacement of any items shall be with identical or equivalent parts only. No change in specifications of any part shall be done. Modification procedure with consent from the Operations Manager shall be followed for all the modifications. All the jobs involving outside contractors shall be done under the close supervision of the Manager-Engineering. Manager-Engineering

shall ensure strict adherence to the necessary permit system. 
So far no modifications have been carried out in the Formaldehyde system. Hence there is no change in the operating procedures. 



Previous safety incidents while handling Formaldehyde 
1) No hazardous incidents took place at ATC Panels Biscoe, Inc., in handling Formaldehyde. 
2) A tanker with rear outlet was received in the past. The unloading area at GVK America is not leveled to accommodate a rear outlet tanker and hence cannot be unloaded fully. It was decided to reject all the tankers with rear outlet. A remark to this effect is included in the Purchase order. 

Containment 
Currently, in case of any accidental release of Formaldehyde, it is collected in the covered ditch. An inflatable rubber cylinder (pig) is stationed at the entrance of the outlet pipe to Town effluent line. In case of Formaldehyde release, to prevent it to go into the town effluent system, the pig will be inserted into the outlet pipe and inflated with air pressure. 
The above procedure was reviewed at the beginning of 2004 and in order to improve on the containment arrangement, a dike wall around the storage tanks and piping was constructed. The dike wall has a containment capacity of 110% of the Formaldehyde tank (25kl). A separate pump provides for the transfer of liquid inside the dike wall into a tanker or a tank. 
With the above containment system, the foreseeable effect on the surrounding communities and local population, in case of catastrophic failure and accidental release of Formaldehyde was reduced, as the spill will be contained indoors. Personnel involved in carrying out the jobs connected with handling of Formaldehyde after any such emergency situation shall wear all the necessary PPE. 

Ventilation 
An exhaust fan is provided in the storage tanks room. The capacity of the fan enables approximately 7.8 air changes per hour. The calculation sheet for the same is attached herewith. It is felt to be adequate for exh

austing any vapors/fumes in case of leakage. 

Conclusion 
After the above process hazard analysis discussion pertaining to Formaldehyde handling, it was concluded that the systems and procedures are adequate for safe handling at ATC Panels Biscoe, Inc. Review of the PHA shall be conducted every 3 years and the next review is scheduled to be done in June 2009.
